Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Despite formaldehyde's high toxicity, it has widespread demand worldwide due to its applications in the synthesis of a plethora of important chemicals like urea-formaldehyde, paraformaldehyde, polyacetal, and biological reagents amongst others. Currently, silver and iron molybdenum oxide catalysts are mostly utilized industrially due to their excellent efficiency and stability. As the catalyst ages and becomes saturated, selectivity decreases, pressure-drop increases, and the temperature of the heat transfer fluid rises. This review aims to present a comprehensive summary of formaldehyde production, considering the fundamentals of the process with a focus on decreasing methanol consumption and the utilization of natural zeolites as renewable, cost-efficiency, abundant and reusable catalysts. Keywords Formaldehyde Methanol Metal oxides Zeolites Sustainable production Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Formaldehyde (CH2O), FA, is a chemical product important to the global economy, widely used as a raw material in the development of a wide variety of industrial product [1,2]. Also known as methanal, metaldehyde, formaldehyde, methyl aldehyde, formic aldehyde or formalin, FA is today one of the most important chemical products produced in the world due to its incomparable reactivity and versatility [3]. This compound exhibits desirable physic-chemical properties such as high stability, good reactivity, high purity, and low price [4]. Other important properties for this compound are summarized in Table 1 . Among the various industrial applications of this compound, its use in the production of urea-formaldehyde [9,10], paraformaldehyde [11], polyacetal [12], phenol formaldehyde [13,14], and biological reagent [1] are cited as the most prevalent. According to the data presented in Fig. 1 , the most common use of formaldehyde is by far as a feedstock for the production of urea-formaldehyde concentrate (UFC) which is used to produce coatings [15], resins [16] and melamine-urea-formaldehyde (MUF) [17]. The second highest consumption source of FA is for the synthesis of phenol formaldehyde (PFA), followed by polyacetal resin (PAR), melamine formaldehyde (MF), diphenyl methane diisocyanate (MDI), pentaerythritol (PE), 1,4-butanediol (BDO) and urotropin (UT). Some other chemicals that can be derived from FA worth mentioning are: polyoxymethylene (POM) [12], pentaerythritol [18], acetylenic chemicals [3], hexamine [19] and methylal (dimethoxymethane) [20,21]. This diversity in application consequently means that a wide range of industrial applications such as construction, automotive, aviation, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics are dependent on formaldehyde [3]. Due to its socioeconomic importance, the demand for industrial production of FA has increased significantly in recent years. FA production capacity in 1900s was only 3 kgtons per year (KTPY) equivalent to about 5 million tonnes (MT) per year [1,5,20]. This value shot up to 12–20 MT in the early 2000s [1,23], reaching 28 MT in 2005 [24], 29 MT in 2010 [25], 46.4 MT in 2012 [5,24] and continuously increased to 52 MT in 2016 [26]. The biggest production occurs in China (34%) with a production of around 11 MT in 2011 [27], followed by the USA (13.9%), Germany (8.9%), Japan (3.7%), Benelux (3.4%), Russia (2.7%), Canada (2.5%), Brazil (2.3%), Poland (1.6%) and Indonesia (1.2%) [7,75–78], as shown in Fig. 2 . Other notable producers include Spain, Italy, and the Republic of Korea. The annual increase in world demand for formaldehyde was estimated at 5% per year during 2011–2016 [27]. This demand tends to continue to grow with the development of the manufacturing industry [28]. Small-scale formaldehyde manufacturing started in Europe and the US in the early 20th century [33]. The development of truly industrial-scale formaldehyde production began in 1910 under the silver-catalyzed process and continued for nearly 40 years. In this process, the mixture of methanol and air was subjected to 600 °C under silver catalyst [28,34] and proceeded according to Eq. (1). The dehydrogenation and redox reactions with or without the involvement of O2 include catalytic combustion. For dehydrogenation using silver (Ag) catalyst, no molecular oxygen is consumed in Reaction (1), although the endothermic reaction takes place at high temperature (650 °C). (1) CH3OH → CH2O + H2 ΔH = 84 kJ/mol Other processes employing hydrocarbon oxidation or carbon monoxide hydrogenation are not industrially significant because they compare unfavorably with methanol conversion in terms of cost or reduced yield [3]. Although it is considered the best method for obtaining FA, the high consumption of methanol and the use of expensive catalysts in the production of FA by methanol conversion methods has been a major concern for many industries [35]. In this sense, considering the economic benefits and the positive impact on society, research has been developed in an attempt to overcome these limitations, using cheaper and “greener” catalysts. This review article mainly discusses the use of new catalysts with the potential to improve FA production to meet global demand, reduce environmental impacts and production cost. 2 Methanol oxidation Currently, over 90% of the global industrial formaldehyde production happens with heterogeneous catalytic methanol oxidation [3,36–39]. In Table 2 several catalysts used for formaldehyde production from methanol oxidation at different temperatures are presented. The iron molybdenum oxide [Fe2(MoO4)3] [40–42] and silver [5,43] catalysts are the most widely utilized. As investigated by Nagy and Mestl [71] in a flow reactor and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) at 180–400 oC and 1 bar, iron molybdenum oxide [Fe2(MoO4)3] catalyst showed 100% selectivity to FA and more than 99% conversion of methanol with 132 kJ/mol of activation energy whereas the molybdenum oxide (MoO3) catalyst showed lower conversion (60–90%) and selectivity (70–100%) [23]. A very high result using molybdenum oxide catalyst was reported by Forzatti et al. [44] in which the obtained selectivity was above 90% with a conversion of 100% [123] and the catalyst was modified over Fe2O3 to MoO3-Fe2(MoO4)3 to improve the reaction performance [45]. Other studies have compared the reaction performance of molybdenum oxide and iron molybdenum oxide catalysts [46]. Su et al. [47] studied the performance of iron molybdenum oxide catalyst at 297–397 oC with 98% conversion and 90% selectivity [48], with by-products of carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), excess of methanol, water, and dimethyl ether (DME) [6,27]. Excess molybdenum (Mo) content on the catalyst could significantly enhance the activity and stability of the catalyst, leading to the higher selectivity due to the larger surface area as reported by Soares et al. [49]. Whereas less Mo content could led to faster deactivation of the catalyst due to smaller surface area and hence diminish selectivity [50]. Factors such as residence time [41], water content [50], temperature, molecular oxygen content in the flow, and extension and stability of the surface area [51] are known to influence the reaction. The effect of different residence times on the performance of catalysts in a fixed bed reactor [41] showed decreasing yield and selectivity caused by longer residence times. The catalyst activity in correlation with temperature was also studied in the isothermal aerobic process [51] showing influence on both conversion and selectivity. Molybdenum oxide catalyst can also be modified/doped with silica (Mo–SiO2) as explored by Yang and Lunsford [52]. N2O and O2 were used as oxidants and silica-based molybdenum oxide (Mo/SiO2) was shown to be a suitable catalyst for FA production. A low selectivity (17.6%) was obtained at high conversion (91%) using N2O oxidant. As stated, the FA produced using the silver catalyst (silver process) requires a methanol-rich feed whereas the FA produced from the iron molybdenum oxide catalyst (FORMOX process) needs an oxygen-rich process gas stream [3,36–38,53,54]. Typically, the metal oxide process can result in higher yields (92%) [1] compared to the silver process at 90% [27]. The catalyst morphology can also affect its performance, as studied by Waterhouse et al. [70]. The study showed that a larger specific surface area led to better activity and higher selectivity due to oxygen chemisorption at the surface as a result of higher availability of catalytic sites. Higher conversion and selectivity of FA were achieved under higher reaction temperature, for example conversions of 60.3% at 325 oC compared to 92.9% at 650 °C, and selectivity of 33.1% at 325 oC compared to 87.1% at 650 °C. The best yield was also obtained at higher temperature [70]. Another study reported a similar observation [71] in which higher selectivity was obtained at higher temperature, increasing to 80% at 427 oC compared to less than 20% at 227 °C. A silver catalyzed membrane reactor [57] revealed a markedly improved performance compared to conventional processes. The membrane was able to improve equilibrium shift by wiping hydrogen and seemed superior economically as well. Some other authors have also investigated membrane reactors for FA production [72–75]. Synthesized vanadium oxide catalysts (V2O5) were in the nineteenth century, promising candidates as catalyst for FA production [32,59,62,64,67,76–87]. Vanadium oxide catalysts supported over SiO2, TiO2, Nb2O5, ZrO2, and Al2O3 materials with surface areas of 300, 50, 55, 39, and 180 m2/g, respectively, were studied by Deo and Wachs [61] at 230 oC and 1 bar. They showed that the increase of the amount of V2O5 phase had positive effect towards selectivity of FA. For instance, a 0.5% of V2O5 addition led to a 66% selectivity, while the selectivity reached 88% with 5% of vanadium oxide loading. Analogues results were obtained using other oxides as substrates, like TiO2, Nb2O5, ZrO2, and Al2O3. The best performance was reported for the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst (99% of selectivity) followed by V2O5/Nb2O5 (97%), V2O5/ZrO2 (94%), V2O5/SiO2 (88%), and V2O5/Al2O3 (46%) [61]. Later, the impact of different oxides as substrates for V2O5 catalysts were studied by Deo and Wachs [88] while the influence of catalyst composition, temperature, and lifetime were explored by Forzatti et al. [89]. A study on SiO2-based catalysts by Music et al. [68] revealed that the selectivity relied on the composition of acid-base and redox sites. Higher yield and longer thermal stability were achieved over pure ZnO/SiO2 catalysts compared to ZnO/SiO2 catalysts synthesized over zeolites and phosphates. Incorporation of Fe oxide improved the ZnO/SiO2 catalyst performance, while on the contrary, loading with other oxides such as Cu, Cr, and In did not lead to significant improvements. The poor conversion and yield of the supported ZnO/SiO2 catalysts were attributed to the deactivation of the ZnO/SiO2 catalyst by Cu, Cr, and In [68]. Hematite (Fe2O3) [23], cobalt molybdate (CoMoO4.H2O) [66], Al2O3 [63], WO3-P2O5 [59], MnOx [90], U3O8-based catalysts [59], and Methylobacterium extorquens [58], have also been used for methanol oxidation, whereas platinum-based materials are efficient for electrochemical assisted applications [56]. The importance of the surface acidity and basicity properties of metal oxides in catalytic activity of methanol oxidation were studied by Mamoru Ai [59] where it was found that FA forms with acidic oxides like WO3, MoO3, V2O5, and U3O8-based catalysts compared with basic oxides like TiO2, Fe2O3, SnO2, Bi2O2, ZnO, and Co2O4. By using Mo/Sn catalyst, conversion increased over higher temperature with the highest being 97% at 232 oC and the lowest being 23% at 187 °C. Whilst, the highest yield obtained under Mo/Sn catalyst was 32% at 226 oC and the highest one obtained under WO3- and U3O8 based catalysts was 87% at 320 oC and 41.2% at 300 °C, successively [59]. 3 Silver and iron molybdenum oxide catalysts Approximately, 20% of the FA production in eighteenth century was obtained with the noncatalytic reaction of butanes and propane, a process with a high running cost, which resulted in a broad spectrum of products [6]. But through decades of innovation, the methanol destined for FA production [91]. Notably, Dynea AS technology [91] uses silver as a catalyst under methanol rich conditions under elevated temperature. Meanwhile, Formox technology uses iron molybdenum oxide as a catalyst with less methanol and at lower temperature [40].The partial oxidation of methanol alongside the by-product reactions and the enthalpy changes are collected in Table 3 . Methanol and air (79% N2 and 21% O2) are utilized in FA production by means of either dehydrogenation reaction or partial oxidation of methanol [92]. Mechanistically, methanol is initially adsorbed on the catalyst surface via Lewis acid sites [93] to create methoxy and hydroxyl clusters. Then in the second step, FA is adsorbed over the catalyst and a second hydroxyl cluster is formed. Afterwards, the hydroxyl clusters are, at the third step, combined to form water. Eventually, oxygen re-oxidizes the catalyst [94–98]. 3.1 Silver catalyst Fig. 3 gives a simple illustration of the FA production process using the silver catalyst. The process flow diagram (PFD) is adapted from Gerberich [6] and Reuss [5,99] as was firstly reported in 1910 [24]. Methanol was, in the early days of the industry, reacted over a copper catalyst [100], which was less efficient. The silver reaction occurs under two simultaneous backlashes in which (50 – 60)% of the formed FA is, in the first reaction, produced exothermically, and the remainder is in the second reaction, produced endothermically [6]. In addition, the yield of FA production, ranges in the range of 86–90% according to the reacted methanol [6]. In this process, the methanol is pumped by centrifugal pump from a tank to the vaporizer and further mixed with the fresh air. A filter is installed to protect the pump from dirt and soil carried along the methanol flow, as well as a filter for the air to remove dirt and dust. Mixing and vaporization occurs and the mixture is heated up to a desired reaction temperature. Additionally, in the water ballast process, water is introduced with a water to methanol weight ratio of 40:60. The mixture is then fed into the main reactor (multitube type) where the silver catalyst with a size of 0.1–0.50 cm is laid on the tubes [91]. The length of the tubes and the diameter of the reactor are 0.1–0.5 m [6] and 1.7–2 m, respectively. Such a system can produce approximately 135,000 tons/year of FA [6,102]. The process gas is exothermically catalyzed by the silver catalyst at 600–680 oC [91] and 1.00 bar to produce the main product with formaldehyde selectivity of 90–92% and with conversion of methanol over 99% [103]. Aside from the formaldehyde, side products such as carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), formic acid (FA), methyl formate (MF), are generated, while unreacted FA and a little bit of unreacted methanol also exist [6]. The products leave the tubes of the reactor and head to an adsorber where water is sprayed from the top to help the adsorption of FA. The FA in the liquid phase in the bottom of the adsorber is pumped into the storage tank, and unreacted methanol is recycled and re-mixed in the process gas to avoid an explosive air–methanol mixture [104]. Dynea technology recommends using the silver catalyst 0.5–1 year, before it is regenerated by electrolysis. The structure of the silver catalyst is face-centered cubic crystal with around 26% of free space. The performance of the catalyst can be affected by factors such as coke poisoning, poor distribution of the heat along the catalyst, and sintering caused by towering reaction temperature and by decomposition of methanol [6]. The risk of extremely elevated reaction temperature is decreased by adding water in the feed which also increases the conversion of methanol, yield of FA, and oxygen content [3]. The process with and without adding water was studied [105] showing that water increased the conversion about four-fold and improve selectivity of FA. The addition of water can also limit the formation of formic acid as a side-product, a compound which is corrosive and can trigger formaldehyde polymerization [105]. Another study [106] found that by adding water, active oxygen species were formed and surface restructuring was promoted which strongly affected preferable selectivity of FA. The best oxygen/methanol feed ratio has been reported at 2.25 [70]. The cooler after the main reactor is used to refrigerate the process gas before going to the absorber in order to facilitate absorption and to avoid product decomposition. The cooled gas is fed to the absorber from the bottom while water is fed from the top. The absorber can yield formalin with concentration up to 55% and methanol content less than 1.5% [6]. Approximately 3–12% of the methanol is added as an inhibitor into the product for stabilization because the formalin is unstable and can be easily polymerized [91]. This can lead to the formation of paraformaldehyde which can block various parts of the setup. Apart from stabilization of the product, it can also reduce formic acid content which enhances product quality [107]. From the absorption tower, two streams emerge. Formalin, unreacted methanol, formic acid, methyl format, and water, leave from the bottom as the main products. Whereas gasses such as CO, CO2, less unabsorbed FA, and a little bit of unreacted methanol are removed from the top as by-products, and burned in a stack gas before being released into the atmosphere. The main product stream is pumped into a distillation tower for purification [5,21]. The distillation tower is utilized to recover methanol through the top, and then frozen by a heat exchanger to liquid methanol which is further recycled into the raw material line. In the bottom of the distillation tower, 55% FA with methanol content of 1.5% is produced and pumped into the FA tank. Furthermore, the products are cooled to decrease the temperature to 65 oC in order to bring down formic acid content which is produced at higher temperature. If required, a de-acid plant/process can be used to decrease formic acid content from more than 200 ppm to less than 50 ppm [5,21]. 3.2 Iron molybdenum oxide catalyst The process for FA produciton using catalysts such as MoO3 and Fe2(MoO4)3 [40,50,93,108–112] is depicted in Fig. 4 . Partial methanol oxidation with air takes place on a metallic oxide catalyst using a fixed-bed vapor phase oxidation reactor with heat transfer fluid (HTF) as a coolant during normal operation. A low ratio of methanol to air in the reaction is used to maintain the desired oxidative atmosphere and concentration of methanol feeding is kept around 6.5–8.5% [24]. Since during shutdown the methanol content at the inlet can increase, and alarm is set to 10.20% [40]. If the oxygen content is over 13%, an elevated methanol content can lead to damages [113]. To maximize the production yield, the Formox technology uses elevated methanol inlet content (> 9 wt.%) and high oxygen content (11 wt.%) [113]. Hence, high alertness is needed to control the process during operation to avoid explosion. Theoretically, this process results in 91–94% yield with very elevated conversion of methanol (99%) and negligible amounts of by-products [1]. Several modifications like utilization of other metal oxides [114] or inert carriers [82] have been proposed to strengthen the performance of the catalyst [1]. It is worth mentioning that about 70% of FA production worldwide uses such a process [6,115]. Fresh air is filtered to remove dirt and dust to avoid damage and impurities in the product. A sand filter may even have to be installed before in some desert countries with a pressure transducer to discern blockage of the filter [113,116]. The filtered air is then steadily supplied by a turbocharger which consists of two parts namely a compressor and a turbine [117,118]. The system pressure is maintained stable by a pressure control valve installed on a blow off line after the compressor to keep constant oxygen content during the process. If the oxygen content is too high, the system pressure must be reduced and/or the recycled process gas must be increased to decrease the oxygen content. Vice versa, if the oxygen content is very low, the system pressure must be increased and/or the recycled process gas must be reduced to increase the oxygen content [1]. The oxygen content kept in the range of 10.50–11.50%, while also controlling methanol content [111] and volatile species [40,49,50,111,119]. In the Formox process (Fig. 5 ), the system uses two centrifugal blowers connected in series in order to apply enough pressure to transport the process gas into the main reactor. Multiple thermo elements are installed in the centrifugal blowers to protect the motors and bearings against elevated temperature which automatically shuts down the blowers. A flow meter and control valve are installed after the blower to measure and control the process gas entering the system [113,120]. Methanol is transported by a pump from a tank and mixed with the process gas in a vaporizer line. The methanol content is kept at 8.5–9.5% in order to maintain the desired oxygen content. To avoid methanol gas from entering the blowers, a check valve is placed after the blower to prevent flow back [113,116,120,121]. The reaction must be in the gas phase because the iron molybdenum oxide catalyst is very sensitive to methanol droplets as well as high methanol content which will lead to irrecoverable damage to the catalyst. That is why the methanol is vaporized from liquid to gas [113,122]. The main multitube shell type reactor is filled by HTF as a cooler. A diameter of about 2.5 m can be accompanied with tubes 1–1.5 m long [6]. Three layers are used: the upper layer is loaded with ceramics for pre-heating, the middle layer is filled with the catalyst, and the bottom layer consists of another ceramic phase for reaction cooling. Thermo elements are installed to monitor the reaction temperature. When the reaction temperature in the main reactor is too high (over 400 °C), in order to avoid undesirable deflagration of the reaction and damage do the vessel, it can be reduced by reducing methanol supply and/or decreasing the HTF temperature. The main reactor is further protected using an inert gas (N2) flow. The process gas and the methanol can be fed to the main reactor at just under 210 °C, and exothermically react to temperatures of more than 330 °C, and are further cooled by the bottom ceramic to 285 oC [203,212] after which the process gas containing FA gas and other byproducts such as carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO), dimethyl ether (DME), formic acid (FA), and unreacted methanol enter the absorber. The selectivity and other parameters will suffer if/when the catalyst ages or is poisoned [24,40,50,93,122–127]. Before heading to the absorber, the process gasses are cooled by the shell side of the vaporizer as methanol is heated from room temperature up to the required temperature on the tube side. A highly active and selective catalyst includes MoO3 and Fe2(MoO4)3 [40,50,119,123,128] in which the active phase is Fe2(MoO4)3 [41,109,110] and MoO3 is utilized to prevent contamination [23,49,50,129]. Catalyst deactivation and subsequent problems are commonly caused by volatilization of MoO3 (and redeposition downstream in the reactor) [124,130,131]. The iron molybdenum oxide catalyst is usually replaced/renewed after 1–2 years at full capacity [93] according to several studies [132–135]. As the process gasses are fed from the bottom of the absorber (around 130 °C), water at (30 °C) is introduced into the absorber from the highest layer to adsorb the process gasses and bring the FA into the liquid phase. Packing is used to provide maximum exchange. Valve trays are used due to large contact surfaces and good flexibility, while bubble cup trays are used to remove the last remnants of FA from the process gas. In addition, a mist eliminator is utilized to stop entrainment of liquid droplets heading to the blowers. The formalin, mostly formed in the bottom section of the absorber, is transported by pump to a formalin tank [6]. Approximately, 40–50% of the process gas coming out from the top of the absorber is continuously recycled into the blowers in order to re-react the remaining methanol with fresh oxygen, while the remainder of the process gas is transferred to the emission control section where Pt/Pd catalysts are used to react the gasses into CO2 and H2O as portrayed in Table 4 . The emission control system consists of pre-heating and a reactor. The preheater increases the temperature to over 190 °C, before the exhaust gasses react using the Pt/Pd catalysts. The exiting gasses are over 450 oC which must be cooled to around 230 oC by the emission control system steam generator [118] and further cooled down to 80 oC using the process gasses coming out from the top absorber [118,121] before release to the environment. 4 Discussion 4.1 Development of the solid catalyst application used in the formaldehyde process Fig. 6 presents milestones regarding the utilization of catalysts for large-scale FA production. The formation of formaldehyde from methylene acetate was firstly reported in 1859 by Aleksandr Butlerov (although it was referred to as "dioxymethylene"). A few years later (1867), August Wilhelm von Hofmann carried out FA synthesis by passing methanol and air flow over heated platinum spiral as a catalyst [5]. In 1882, FA was produced industrially with good yield after Tollens showed a better method [5]. An important breakthrough happened in 1910 when Hugo and Blank found that the incorporation of silver can lead to enhanced production capacity, higher yield, and good efficiency. Afterwards, Badische Anilin and Soda-Fabrik commercially produced FA using a crystalline silver catalyst, a catalyst utilized since 1925 until today [136]. In recent decades, with the development of iron molybdenum oxides, the highest conversion, selectivity, yield in combination with economic feasibility and regenerability was obtained with Formox technology [116]. A list of studies using the popular catalysts is provided in Table 5 [3,23,36,40,43,51,70,102,105,137–147]. Reuss et al. [5] compared catalysts in a study where the reaction using the silver was carried out at 600–720 oC and the reaction using the iron molybdenum oxide was carried out at 270–400 °C. The recorded conversion over the iron molybdenum oxide (98–99%) was higher than that of silver (77–87%). Based on that study, the reaction using the iron molybdenum oxide is more efficient than the one using silver due to higher conversion at lower temperature. A novelty in the report was that in the case of silver, FA formation was carried out under adiabatic conditions [5]. Comparison between the iron molybdenum oxide and the silver catalyst was also carried out by Gerberich and Seaman [6] where the temperature of the silver catalyst (over 600 °C) was higher than that of the iron molybdenum oxide catalyst (above 250 °C). A larger yield (88–92%) was, achieved over the iron molybdenum oxide catalyst, compared to the silver catalyst was (86–90%). Gerberich and Seaman [6] also claimed that the process using iron molybdenum oxide is better than the process using silver catalyst due to upper yield at lower temperature in which more than 99% methanol conversion was obtained [6]. 4.2 Optimizing the formaldehyde production To obtain a high company profit in the FA production, some authors and researchers have invariably explored how to enhance the conversion, yield, selectivity, and the catalyst capability. Furthermore, these applied improvements have been conducted to bring down the methanol consumption by various methods. For instance, Song and Hwang [57] explored how to get higher conversion in FA production at 300–400 oC and 1.00 bars. In the experiments, different temperatures, methanol:air feed ratios, duration and membrane areas were investigated. Good numerical data was obtained over the kinetic two-step model [148]. Waterhouse et al. [70] studied the influence and the role of various surface oxygen species like Oα, Oβ, Oᵞ and oxygen speciation toward selectivity of FA in a wide range of temperatures and methanol:oxygen ratios. According to their study, the ratio of Oᵞ/Oα strongly affected the selectivity and the highest yield of formaldehyde of 84.3% was achieved for a methanol:oxygen ratio of 2.25 at 650 °C. Approximately, 90–92% selectivity and over 99% conversion were achieved via addition of water and fast cooling of reaction products [70]. The influence of oxygen species such as Oα, Oβ, Oᵞ were also explored by other authors [38,71,105,106,149–160]. Time-on-stream (TOS) and temperature reaction also affect the performance of the silver catalyst toward in which longer TOS and more elevated temperature resulted in higher conversion and selectivity due to good oxygen chemisorption. TOS is defined as the reaction time [103]. Catalyst restructuring at certain conditions (for example at 650 °C) has been reported. In the said study the catalyst restructured to create good surface facets with dimensions of 1-2 µm [160]. Other studies have reported optimum results at 500 oC [161]. The influence of temperatures, methanol content, oxygen content, velocity of gas, space velocity, and surface area toward the results were also investigated by Lefferts et al. [36] showing that when a more elevated temperature, less methanol content, higher oxygen content, shorter space velocity, and more upper gas velocity were applied in the reaction, a higher conversion was obtained. Increased selectivity at higher temperature has also been reported elsewhere [162]. Modification of the silver catalyst by doping Ag over Congo Red (CR@Ag) to enhance the activity and increase conversion and selectivity were explored by Shter et al. [163]. Conversion of methanol improved with temperature: 40% at 325 °C, 70% at 400 °C, and 95% at 500 oC where the selectivity (96%) achieved over the CR@Ag catalyst was higher than the pure silver catalyst (73%) at the same temperature reaction. Further improvement of the silver catalyst has been investigated by Behar-Levy [164–167] and Nesher et al. [168,169] while bactericidal agents were utilized by Ben-Knaz [170]. TiO2-modified CR@Ag catalyst was reported by Aouat et al. [171] to enhance the conversion reaching a value of 98%. Torbina et al. [172] have reviewed the modification of the silver catalyst composition to improve the conversion of methanol and the selectivity for FA. For example, for metallic Ag fibers, the highest conversion was 94.2% with a good selectivity (82.4%). Elsewhere, Halperin et al. [173] used Ag–C fibers and Ag metal fibers in order to compare their performances in methanol oxidation, while the influence of sintering parameters on the morphology of the catalyst was investigated. In comparison, the Ag–C fibers catalyst was slightly better than the Ag metal fibers catalyst due to the higher conversion (95.8% vs 94.2%) and selectivity (84.1% vs 82.4%). Industrial FA production with approximately (3–12 wt.%) of methanol fed into the reaction and recycled into the process gas to avoid an explosive air – methanol range has obtained selectivity in the range of 90–92% [103]. The silver catalyst was regenerated with electrolysis after one year of use. Whilst, the conversion and yield were increased by adding water into the feed with a methanol:water ratio of 60:40 wt.% to reduce overheating and to improve oxygen content [3]. This argument was also supported by Bao et al. [106] and Qian et al. [105] where the addition of water into the process had a positive effect in the upper conversion and selectivity and decreased production of formic acid as by-product [105]. Water also had positive effect on the silver catalyst surface and on the formation of active Oᵞ species. The interaction of oxygen and silver has been investigated [70,152,160,174,175] and the silver catalyst has also been used for CO oxidation [176]. Li et al. [177] mostly used silver nanoparticles in the ethylene process [178] and the alcohol oxidation process [3,174]. Using silver nanoparticle can increase the selectivity and the catalytic activity [179–181]. The Formox technology referred to earlier [46,182–185] owes its economic advantage to a large extent to its lower process temperature. Rellan-Pineiro and López [186] explored the use of iron molybdenum oxide catalyst and performed density functional theory analysis for the reaction network and active sites, resulting in the claim that MoVI–MoIV pairs were the most selective and highly active sites. It has been reported that isotropic Fe2(MoO4)3 is much more active than the anisotropic MoO3 in consequence of larger active sites [187,188]. This is in line with general research consensus that Fe2(MoO4)3 is more active [46,184,185,189], however, the excess MoO3 is important for improving selectivity and longer life time [26,42,190–192] in addition to activity [49,50,108,119]. Modification of the α-MoO3 and β-MoO3 catalysts has been explored [189,193] whereby using soft chemical transformation by adding HNO3 to α-MoO3 followed by drying and calcination, β-MoO3 was synthesized. The best performances were achieved over β-MoO3 catalyst due to a higher activity and higher surface area compared to α-MoO3. In addition, the larger amount of Lewis acid sites and the higher acidity of the β-MoO3 surface were found to be crucial factors [193]. Pudge [22] harnessed malonic acid solvents in synthesis of the catalyst using the malonate method in which influence of Fe:Mo ratio and addition of water into the reaction were studied. The best yield resulted at Fe:Mo ratio of 1:1.7. The malonate method was dramatically affected by calcination time and temperature. Nanoparticle of iron molybdenum oxide synthesized by heating oxalate precursors at 500 oC were explored by Hassani [194] where decreasing nitrophenol isomers to ortho, meta, and paranitrophenol isomers resulted in high catalytic efficiency. Other methods for synthesis of the iron molybdenum oxide nanoparticles such as precipitation method [195], solvothermal [196], hydrothermal [60], and microwave-hydrothermal method [197] have also been investigated [49,51,60,108,145,198]. Apart of above mentioned methods for improving the process, Bowker et al. [147] studied the influence of hematite (α-Fe2O3) doping on the surface of the catalyst areas. Also, Mo loading or various reaction temperatures were observed. For both the MoO3 catalyst and the α-Fe2O3 catalyst, the conversion was upgraded over higher temperature. However, the selectivity using the α-Fe2O3 catalyst was worse than the MoO3 catalyst. Brookes et al. [192] stated that the selective and active site of the iron molybdenum oxide catalyst are the octahedral Mo units, while other authors expressed that Fe2(MoO4)3 acts as a supporter for the molybdenum oxide sites that are responsible for the elevated catalytic activity [42,49,108]. Brookes et al. [191] also observed that some of the Mo transformed into Fe2(MoO4)3 at temperature over 400 °C, whilst at lower temperature, nanoparticles of the MoO3 catalyst do not convert. Additionally, it was mentioned that the octahedral Mo surface area does not alter in spite of calcination even up to 600 oC [191]. The influence of annealing revealed that thermal treatment at 500 oC led to 92% selectivity and 90% conversion while at 300 oC the selectivity dropped to 80% with the conversion remaining the same [191]. Soderhjelm et al. [24], examined different Mo:Fe ratios as well as different Fe2O3 and MoO3 contents. Regarding the selectivity, an upward trend was reported by elevating the Mo:Fe ratio. For instance, the lowest selectivity of 18% was obtained for a Mo:Fe ratio of 0.2 and the highest (90%) was achieved at the highest Mo:Fe ratio of 2.2, with the conversion of about 90% for both cases. A mixture of MoO3 and Fe2(MoO4)3 nanoparticles was the best catalyst in the process which was attributed to the synergistic effect between MoO3 and Fe2(MoO4)3. Similar to the previous report , increase of the Mo:Fe ratio led to the increase of selectivity as reported by Routray et al. [42] at 300o C with a flow rate of 100 mL/min. The selectivity obtained over Fe2O3 alone was 48% whereas the highest obtained over the MoO3 alone was 65%. On the contrary, mixtures of the Fe2O3 and the MoO3 with Mo:Fe ratio of 1.5, 1.7, and 2.0 resulted in selectivity of 75%, 87%, and 88%, respectively, at the same temperature. The researchers further claimed that the catalytic performance of the process could be upgraded using nanoparticles, and with different methods of calcination and drying [199]. Patents on such issues can be found as early as the nineteenth century [46,69,206–209,185,187,200–205] and the influence of the Mo:Fe ratio on performance has been additionally studied by other authors [110,123,210]. In order to obtain excess molybdenum oxide by co-precipitation, synthesis at pH of 2 and calcination at 420 oC have been tested [45,211]. Sun-Kou et al. [123] reported that elevated catalytic activity was achieved under excess Mo phase and Trifiro et al. [212] claimed that the excess Mo catalyst was required due to enhancing properties of the catalyst, accomplishing higher Mo:Fe ratio of 1.5, and allowing re-oxidation reaction. Moreover, the obtained selectivity over the excess Mo catalyst was higher compared to without excess, as reported by Soares et al. [49] and Routray et al. [42]. Calcination temperature played a key role on various physicochemical properties of the final material, importantly on the phases composition [213–217] as well as the variation of the redox or acid-base sites [201,202,218,219]. In addition, high calcination temperature had a positive impact on selectivity [108] although CO as by-product was, unfortunately, produced as well [220]. Synthesizing iron molybdenum oxide catalyst over silica as reported by Yang and Lunsford [52] improved catalyst activity. Addition of water in high amount into the reaction could cause conversion decrement, but on the contrary, the effect on selectivity was positive. The conversion and selectivity obtained under 4 torr of water were 18.5% and 90%, respectively, whilst, at 27.1 torr of water they became 11.3% and 96% [52]. In addition, it was suggested that the most active phase in formaldehyde production was Mo2O5. Ivanov et al. [198] showed that the oxygen content in the process gas must be higher than the methanol content because the very high methanol content in the mixture feeding into the reactor led to a dramatic change in the temperature profile. The best selectivity was achieved over methanol content of 5%, space velocity of 6800/h, oxygen content of 8.6–12.8%, and water content of 3–6%. It obviously seems that the results and the catalyst ability can be maximally upgraded by optimizing operating parameters, metal oxides supported into the catalyst, nano-sized catalyst particles, and less water addition into the process. In authors view, the best method to jack up the catalyst performance and to achieve the optimal results is by optimizing process condition because it does not require any extra process budget. 4.3 Comparison of the catalyst performance between silver and iron molybdenum oxide On the whole, the comparison of the two notable catalysts are briefly summarized in Table 6 . The catalysts come in different shapes as seen in the list. Also, the lifetime for the silver is 1–1.5 years whereas for the iron molybdenum oxide it is longer (1.5 – 2 years) [40]. The silver catalyst is usually laid on the strainer above the tubes whereas the oxide catalyst is inside the tube. Moreover, as stated earlier, the silver process is carried out at higher temperature compared to the oxide process, at the same pressure. The percentage of methanol inlet in the silver process is higher in the silver process (8–12% vs. 7–10% in the oxide process). A superiority of the oxide process is the resulted high conversion (almost 100%), selectivity (almost 100%), and yield (up to 94%) while the silver process results in a lower quality product. Nonetheless, the silver process produces formaldehyde with low formic acid content (150–200 ppm) and the unreacted methanol is further recycled into the system [43] whereas the oxide process contains a higher formic acid content (above 200 ppm) so it is required a deacidify the product to decrease the formic acid content to less than 100 ppm. The silver process'reactor consists of 400 cm wide catalyst bed and 3 cm layer of the filled catalyst [43] with a space velocity of 300,000 per hour to reduce product loss. To reduce the operating temperature and to increase the methanol conversion, the vent gasses is recirculated so that concentration of formaldehyde is escalated up to 55% [43]. The conversion and yield can be increased by adding inert materials to the reaction such as water and nitrogen [221]. Nevertheless, the lifetime of the silver catalyst can be poisoned by sulfur and metals [6] leading to lower the catalyst performance and low-grade product quality with the methanol content of 1.5% [6]. The oxide process'reactor is heated by the circulation of a heat transfer fluid at start up but it is cooled by it during normal operation to maintain the reactor temperature so that the selectivity of formaldehyde is stable [43]. The diameter of the reactor tubes are smaller to improve heat transfer and the oxide catalyst is filled in rings to reduce pressure drop where the space velocity is higher than 8000 perhour [43]. The best activity of the catalyst is achieved at atomic ratio of 1.7 because the excess ferric acid in the catalyst results in less selectivity. So, to increase selectivity and yield, excess molybdenum in the catalyst is required to obtain the best quality where the maximum ratio is around 2.0 [43,222]. Deactivation of the catalyst shows itself through increasing HTF temperature, reactor temperature, pressure drop, and decreasing selectivity [40]. 5 Reducing methanol consumption Various factors can impact the cost of formaldehyde production, one of which is lower methanol consumption. Methanol is an essential material in the process because the price of pure methanol is relatively high 250–500 US$ per metric ton [112]. Considering the above, most industries producing formaldehyde still perform active research on how to decrease methanol consumption while increasing the efficiency in order to enhance profits. The efficiency factor can be derived based on the consumed methanol (Kg) added by the fresh air supply to produce FA with 37 wt.% purity (metric tons, MT). (2) Eff = ( Methanol consumption ( Kg ) + Fresh air supply ( kg ) ( Formaldehyde production ( MT ) For instance, if the efficiency factor of production is around 450 kg methanol/MT-37%-FA it means that 450 kg of methanol is needed to produce 1 ton of 37% FA. The more methanol that is consumed to produce FA, the more improvements in the process are necessary. Economic feasibiltiy will in general be suitable with less than 400 kg MeOH/MT-37%-FA. Ivanov et al. [198] maximized the reaction to produce more FA by using a methanol content of 5–8%. Low methanol content caused higher selectivity of FA because more air was available to react with the methanol. Conversion of methanol obtained was approximately 99% and the selectivities resulting with 5–8% methanol in the reactor were 91.8%, 91.4%, 90.7%, and 85.3%, respectively [198]. Higher methanol content is known to decrease selectivity [223]. Careful control of the HTF is very imporant because it will affect the hot-spot temperature in the reactor [198]. Formox suggested that the good hot-spot position in the reactor takes place in the second or third layer and to maintain the hot-spot position on the exact place, the HTF pressure and temperature must be monitored and controlled. Process gas flow also shows important influence on productivity, with higher process gas flow resulting in higher selectivity [291]. Supply of oxygen into the process based on the stoichiometric reaction is half as much as methanol meaning that twice as much oxygen is needed. In one process, increasing the air flow from 4800 to 6800 kg/h, resulted in a selectivity improvement from 89 to 90.5% [198]. Meanwhile, the selectivities obtained from an oxygen content of 6%, 7%, 8.6%, 10.7%, and 12.8% were 89.9%, 90.1%, 90.6%, 90.5%, and 90.5%, respectively [291]. Nevertheless, care must be taken because there is a risk of plant shutdown or even explosion at oxygen concentration over 13% (with methanol content of 6.5%). Hence, it will be safer to operate the plant at 11% oxygen and very slowly adjusting system pressure [113]. Jiru et al. [224] have observed that water did not inhibit the reaction of FA and it even helped increase the speed of the reaction. Pernicone et al. [182,225,226] observed the opposite, concluding that the water had inhibitory effects because water and methanol competitively adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst, bothering the reaction between methanol and air [198]. Santacesaria et al. [227] and Ivanov et al. [198] have rejected Pernicone's opinion and agreed that water content in the feed had a good contribution on conversion and selectivity. The selectivity obtained from the methanol with zero water content was 84.9% and the presence of 3% water content in the feed increased the selectivity of FA up to 89.7% [198]. A water content of 6% changed the temperature profile of the reactor. The ideal water content in the feed was proposed at 2.5–3.5% to maintain the stability of the reactor temperature. 6 Zeolites Production of FA using metal catalysts as discussed above is the industry standard. Nevertheless, research for well performing and of cheaper materials is still important. Zeolites can be assumed as attractive candidates, not only because of the potential reduction of catalyst cost, but also due to the fact that they are an abundantly available natural resource. Although attractive results have been obtained, still, more knowledge is required before wide industrial adoption [228–238]. As can be seen from Table 7 , this family of catalysts have potential in future FA production in place of (or alongside) metal catalysts. One of the first studies to utilize zeolite catalysts in FA production was carried out by Anderson and Tsai [230] using ZSM-5. This study was not very successful because it resulted in very low conversion (0.1–2.7%) and poor selectivity (0.9–2.2%). Subsequent studies tried to build on the previous work. For example, Banares et al. [237] reached up to 6.7% conversion with 8.8% selectivity using USY zeolite synthesized over MoO3 at over 500 oC a few years later [237]. With further improvements, Music et al. [68] used ZSM-5 zeolite modified over Na and Cu and reached conversion of up to 45.9% with a selectivity of 69.9% operating at a pressure of 1 bar and temperature of 500 °C. The ZSM-5 zeolite modified with Cu resulted in a higher conversion than modified over Na. The longer the duration, the higher the selectivity. For instance, 12.8, 52.3, and 72.3% of selectivity were obtained during time on stream of 2 h, 20 h, and 40 h, respectively [68]. The use of ZSM-5 zeolite as catalyst in FA synthesis was also applied by Lucas et al. [231] with the synthesized catalysts loaded with 0.3–11.9% of tungsten. The selectivity was observed to be strongly influenced by the loading and dispersion of the tungsten on the zeolite surface, although even the best conversion and selectivity obtained was nowhere near the benchmark set by metallic catalysts. Elsewhere, Zhao et al. [239] utilized cycled storage-discharge (CSD) to remove low concentration FA from air and revealed that HZSM-5 zeolite treated by AgCu was the best catalyst in adsorption capacity of FA, pointing at the synergistic influence of Ag and Cu. The modification of ZSM-5 zeolite was also attempted by Morooka et al. [107] harnessing HZSM-5 and NaZSM-5 zeolites synthesized over Fe with different iron contents. Better conversion of methane was achieved with low Si/Fe ratio but the best selectivity for FA production was obtained with the highest Si/Fe ratio. The sodium content had a negative effect on the formation of FA and carbon dioxide [232]. This finding contrasts the work of Matsumura et al. [240] who used Na-ZSM-5 zeolite synthesized over aluminum in the reaction at 477 oC and reported that sodium ions in ZSM-5 zeolite had a positive effect in increasing the conversion and selectivity [240]. It was mentioned that active sites of the catalyst played a significant role in the reaction [241]. One study [242] synthesized the ZSM-5 zeolite with boron at 600 oC for 98 h also stated that the best selectivity was achieved at the maximum sodium concentration. Elsewhere, ZSM-5 zeolite decorated with Cs and Na [243] showed 65% selectivity and 100% of conversion. So, from these seemingly contradictory results, it may be speculated that without the presence of iron, sodium may have a positive role; whereas in the presence of iron the positive effect of sodium could be negated. Such assertions require further scrutiny. Beznis et al. [229] studied formaldehyde synthesis over Co-ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst and emphasized the importance of the preparation method. Synthesis through the ion-exchange method led to higher selectivity for FA than the impregnation method. A year later, Beznis et al. [228] investigated alkaline and acid methods in the synthesis at 150 oC and reported that higher FA selectivity was obtained through acid treatment due to high dispersion of Co2+ on the surface of the ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst. Fellah and Onal [234] proposed using N2O over vanadium in the ZSM-5 catalyst and expressed that [O-V-O]1+ sites on the ZSM-5 zeolite could aid the FA reaction [234]. Other than FA production ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst has been utilized for separation of C4 olefins as reported by Mahdi and Muraza [244] and in carbonylation of FA to methyl glycolate as reported by Barri and Chadwick [236]. The ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst produced the highest yield compared to Y zeolite and mordenite zeolite with less by-products whereas using resins resulted in high yield of by-products. Mordenite, FER, BEA, and ZSM-5 zeolites modified over Fe [245,246] and Cu [247,248] were also selectively used in methane oxidation at low temperature [249,250], in hydrocarbon oxidation [251–254], and in isobutylene reaction to octane-booster compounds [255]. In these studies zeolite have shown to be more selective and active, showing good stability, high selectivity, regenerability, and easy separation [236]. Generally, one promising catalyst in FA synthesis is vanadium oxide which has shown good results when synthesized over SiO2, TiO2, Nb2O5, ZrO2, and Al2O3 with selectivity often exceeding 90%. Therefore it is logical that methanol oxidation to FA using BEA-zeolite with vanadium (V) content was investigated by Trejda et al. [233]. The V on the BEA-zeolite catalyst formed basic (O2-) and Lewis acidic (V5+) centers. The higher vanadium content on the SiBEA-zeolite catalyst caused a high affinity of Lewis acidic centers leading to higher selectivity and conversion. On the other hand, the SiBEA-zeolite untreated by vanadium resulted in the highest conversion (11.2%) but FA was not produced. By adding more vanadium the conversion increased from just over 1% to over 5%, while the selectivity increased to as high as 63% [233]. Elsewhere [235] it was shown that SiBEA-zeolite had lower density of Lewis acidic centers and Bronsted acidic centers than the one synthesized over vanadium. Also, lower V content on the zeolite structure lead to higher Lewis acidic centers with poor Bronsted acidic centers. The Bronsted acidic centers on the SiBEA-zeolite, V0.7SiBEA-zeolite, and V6.0SiBEA-zeolite were 8.7 x 1017, 57.8 x 1017, and 141.2 x 1017, respectively, and affected the obtained conversion and selectivity. The SiBEA-zeolite, V0.7SiBEA-zeolite and V6.0SiBEA-zeolite had 5%, 5% and 21% conversion, respectively, with the later showing 56% selectivity [235]. The influence of vanadium content has been investigated by other authors [234,256–265] and density functional theory (DFT) has been used in this regard [264,266–270]. 7 Conclusions and future recommendations The demand for FA is intensively and continuously increasing year-by-year. FA has garnered significant attention from numerous countries because it is utilized in the production of many chemicals, including urea-formaldehyde, paraformaldehyde, polyacetal, biological reagent, and others. The global FA demand is projected to grow at a rate of 5% per year with a global production of up to 52 MT. China is expected to dominate global FA production (about one third), followed by the USA, Germany, Japan, Russia, Canada, Brazil, Poland, and Indonesia with approximate shares of 14%, 8.4%, 4.2%, 3.5%, 2.5%, 2.2%, 2.2%, 1.4%, and 1.3%, respectively. The vast production and consumption of FA has motivated many researchers to search for improvements towards optimizing various components of the process, not least the catalyst. The aim of research regarding catalysts has been to reduce costs (and environmental impacts) while improving (or at least not reducing) the selectivity, conversion, yield and stability. There are many catalysts which have been tested for FA production such as vanadium oxide, platinum, titania, chromium, hematite, silver, and iron molybdenum oxide. Nevertheless, among the effective catalysts, silver and iron molybdenum oxide catalysts have been preferred worldwide due to their superior performance. Among these two, the iron molybdenum oxide has gained ground as the most widely used and most efficient catalyst, with a lower operating temperature and methanol consumption. Currently, reducing the costs of FA production is a key in the success of the overall process and can be attained through several ways. The first method is to use less methanol because each ton of methanol can cost 300–500 US$ per metric ton. Reducing operational parameters such as temperature or residence time can also lead to reduced costs. On the other hand, another approach for cost reduction is to employ an alternative catalyst such as zeolites which are natural and abundantly available. Zeolites-based catalyst has shown to be a promising class of catalysts but require further research before they can be employed on a wide industrial scale. coredata.dc:description: Despite formaldehyde's high toxicity, it has widespread demand worldwide due to its applications in the synthesis of a plethora of important chemicals like urea-formaldehyde, paraformaldehyde, polyacetal, and biological reagents amongst others. Currently, silver and iron molybdenum oxide catalysts are mostly utilized industrially due to their excellent efficiency and stability. As the catalyst ages and becomes saturated, selectivity decreases, pressure-drop increases, and the temperature of the heat transfer fluid rises. This review aims to present a comprehensive summary of formaldehyde production, considering the fundamentals of the process with a focus on decreasing methanol consumption and the utilization of natural zeolites as renewable, cost-efficiency, abundant and reusable catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Formaldehyde production using methanol and heterogeneous solid catalysts: A comprehensive review
